intro: Gynoxys metcalfii, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows as an annual herb with hairy stems and elongated leaves. Its vibrant orange to red flowers bloom in the summer months, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Gynoxys metcalfii is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is relatively easy to grow in well-drained soil.
